Anonymous Thu 16 Apr 2020 03:21:29 No.29647533 Report
Quoted By: >>29648807 >>29654723 >>29657086
>>29647240
Aww, I wanted to repost it. Anyways, since I’ve seen nobody respond to it so far, I’ll repost my paragraphs on Were It Not For You.

I didn’t like how in Were It Not For You, everything seemingly just works out. I wanted more drama with Anon. Maybe it would be better if he didn’t connect with the waifur so fast. He started out hating anthros right? And then he just... stops hating them all of a sudden? That didn’t make sense to me.

If I were to recreate Were It Not For You, I would make it less a romance and more a story of a waifur who was a saved by a human and how she tries to break him out of his shell. His “shell” being his hatred for anthros (which doesn’t just magically go away like in the actual story), his previous homelessness and drug use, and years of being away from his family, who he will never see again. Romance would not even be an idea until the end, it would be much more cynical and focus on the worse aspects of Anon’s character.

>>29647281

Personally I would (and will) rewrite the initial interactions between Anonathan and Julia in HSR, I feels as if I did a poor job detailing initial attractions from Julia and I'll likely retcon the the police scene I wrote after getting a ticket.

As for another story I would change part of Roo'd Awakening where Anon changes the oil in Ruby's car, personally I think I would've had it be a little more, perhaps changing break pads, its equally simple though lesser known. I think this minor change would be more impact later on.
Also that and Anon's comment Apology Accepted in reference to Ruby referring to his car as a junker despite it being a hand-me-down.
Further still on that chapter that masturbation scene was quite frankly, out of left field, I would've added a paragraph or two of lead up perhaps a tiny bit of foreshadowing.
Lastly in regards to the whole story, while I won't hold Comfy's update cycle against him, small updates and short stories to whet the appetite of the readers and make them want more is a skill he lacks.
I say this because this would lead most to believe you died or left, while a hit to reader numbers is unlikely to effect a thread celebrity like Comfy or Oliver, it does to the rest of us rabble and is a point worth mentioning in terms of discussion

Anonymous Thu 16 Apr 2020 04:56:38 No.29649375 Report
Quoted By:
>>29648695
I'm a little sleep deprived but I feel the need to elaborate how Truby SHOWS a moral argument through story telling.
1st you have a design principle, a single sentence idea that you build your story around.
>what if anon married a rich waifur
2nd you base a "theme" off this design principle. A theme is described as "a single sentence describing your vision of the right way to live."
>"you shouldn't mooch off your loved ones for cash but instead earn your own money"
3rd You create the argument for your theme by stating an immoral action your character does, it being criticized and then your character defending that immoral action.
>mc does something wrong i.e. takes cash out of his waifurs wallet to pay for his friends meal
>mc gets criticized i.e. anons friends chastise him when they learn he stole his money from his waifur.
>mc defends himself i.e. "I'm fucking paying for your meals as your friend. Bros before hoes remember?"
4th during or after the climax, the hero has a self revelation, an action which shows theyve learned to stop being immoral.
>"anon gets a shitty job and with his new income pays for a vacation for his rich waifur"
5th create a choice for the mc between two equally bad or equally good that occurs after the self revelation. The choice he chooses reinforces the theme and self revelation.
>anon can either go to jail or lose his waifur. He chooses to go to jail.
I didnt include details such as the seven steps and character details that make this moral argument equation into an actual story instead of a preachy fable. The point is, the human memoirs had a self revelation and a choice. But instead of showing the argument for those choices, like with step number 3, the author just says the arguments through the mc's thoughts. There are no points in the plot where he does something immoral, is criticized, then defends it. It is purely "I didn't feel good about this in the past so I'm going to not do it."
Sorry for the rant.
Anonymous

Anonymous Thu 16 Apr 2020 06:22:38 No.29650756 Report
Quoted By:
>>29648695
>truby has in his "22 steps"
Part of the reason I dislike Truby is his advice gets taken as a paint by numbers by too many.
In a movie or screenplay, you need to decide which and how many of these steps are needed to show the backstory and psychology. In many movies, and particularly ones with a heavy action component, these steps reflect doing something.
In a longer story the steps have more leisure, but any scene which isn't contributing to the framework needs to feel as if it contains psychological information. If it does, the readier/viewer gets a breather. If not, fluff.

What near every summary of Truby gets wrong is that a fleshed out story will have elements of these steps whether or not the writer planned them. You can't checklist your way out of knowing your character's psychology. You can checklist your way into supporting characters and villains that have zero depth.
I prefer breaking things into quarters and checking my pacing. What major events happened close to then or spot on? Did each scene do something to advance/increase the plot/tension/stakes/character conflict? How does each connect to other elements?
Applied psychology is a hell of a multi-tool in a writer's kit. Ignore it, and in the case of a movie you end up with two hours of demo reel for the technical artists.
Anonymous

  • Report

First I want to take the time to say thank you for taking the time to type out this criticism/feedback for me Smiling, I seriously appreciate it. I agree that I could've added some more lesser known stuff like changing brake pads to give it a little more impact and to flesh out the fact that Anon knows his way around a car, though the only thing that stopped me from doing so at the time is that scene was already fairly long and could've been more boring to read to someone not interested in car stuff as a result. This >>29647945 stuff I would've also liked to add but I was mostly concerned with length and pacing issues since it's something I know I need to work on.

If I'm remembering right she does apologize a bit further down the line for that comment about his car though it was probably unneeded at the time, yeah. I completely agree with the masturbation scene needing a bit more build up or foreshadowing since it came out of nowhere, I'll note down to give that part some closer attention when I eventually rewrite the greentext bits into prose. As for the bit about my update cycle, I can't really disagree about it being a skill I lack, though it's something I want to work on being better at. The last thing I want is for year long waits to be the norm with me so after this update I'm trying to figure out a way to get smaller, yet plot significant updates out more frequently. I seriously appreciate the honesty in the feedback, I'll take it to heart as I keep writing the story, thank you.

Anonymous Thu 16 Apr 2020 08:52:57 No.29652538 Report
Quoted By: >>29652650
>>29652162
No worries, I'm always happy to respond to constructive criticism since it helps a lot. Now, I don't claim to be an expert or anything since I've had actual Aussie anons critique the dialogue here in the thread before but I think it's important to watch videos of people from that region speaking in normal conversation and looking into regional slang to help clue in readers to what kind of accent you're going for. That being said, don't use slang that's too obscure or at least provide context clues as to what you're talking about if it's not clear what the word means. And since it was something I was critiqued on, be careful of using slang too frequently or stereotypically which makes it come off as inauthentic or overplayed to anyone who's actually from the region who's accent you're trying to write. Spending a lot of time playing around with the dialogue after you've written the first draft and change it around until you feel like it sounds convincing enough will help a lot in the long term. Hopefully this is actually helpful advice and not just me rambling.
Anonymous

Anonymous Fri 17 Apr 2020 03:38:47 No.29668986 Report

Here's a snippet from the first draft of a story I'm working on. It's nothing much, and I'm mostly just posting to give myself something to be beholden to.

Rob played on an arcade machine. Some other staff stood around the rec area, chatting. On the white wall there was a whiteboard.
'IMPORTANT THINGS TO REMEMBER'
1. Ration your food.
2. Keep in contact.
3. Keep it professional.
4. Do the checks.
5. The local stations are better.
Another guy was standing next to Rob, leaning over and looking at the screen. Rob missed the jump and fell. A tinny 'bewoop' sound came out and the game restarted. He stood up.
"Your turn."
Rob walked off to the vending machine and grabbed a snack. Then he picked a random group and stood near them.
"Hey."
"Hey" a man responded. He had on a jumpsuit like Rob, but his had orange patches, with orange lines on the rubber boots.
"How's the trip been?"
"Good." A woman responded. She had purple on her jumpsuit. "It's been weird though. Like we're in our own little bubble."
"Definitely."
